column4: hi, how can I tell whether the installed OS is ubuntu server or ubuntu desktop?

ok but I noticed in my desktop when a kernel update is available, a file  /var/run/reboot... is created, now in my server I don't get that file so I don't know when to reboot, I thought may be the server does it in a different way
im sure its a difference in attitude. on a desktop you might have unattended upgrades. do that on a server and you deserve to die
why? I have it installed and doing the security updates

from http://serverfault.com/questions/92932/how-does-ubuntu-keep-track-of-the-system-restart-required-flag-in-motd see Note: for debian systems, /var/run/reboot-required does not get created unless the update-notifier-common package is installed. – Peter V. Mørch Jan 27 at 7:50
ive seen only 2GB or so on 32bit non pae. just need a nice shiny graphics card
like my previous employer... who got the high end machine for the developers, but put 32bit non-pae kernels on it. so that really nice 2GB video card meant i had less usable ram than the other guys
sorry I didn't understand the relation between the video card ram and pae kernels, you mean with non-pae 32-bits if you have 4G RAM and 2G vga-card you are going to use only 2G total?
if its DMA'able then it counts against the address space
then what's the mapping rule? 1G from vga and 1G from RAM, or just 2G vga and 0 RAM ;)

anything the card sets up is gone. and we were using windows so there was no way for me to blacklist the cards memory space or tell it to steal less of my ram. it was just *gone* and there was nothing i could do about it
funny, but can you even do this in linux? I mean blacklist the cards memory?

so that 3.2 is really based on averages. video cards have gotten more sane in recent years and you dont see as many 2GB cards out there. but theoretically with the right hardware it would be impossible to boot a system because it ran out of RAM
i dont know if you can blacklist, but i imagine you probably could. point was i was very annoyed that our development team who worked with large data sets had less ram than everyone else on the floor
i think in theory it could do with less, but Flannel seems to be backed by the docs and swsusp is rather simplistic
